Philadelphia, PA 19104-6299
Heidy Sarabia, Ph.D.
heidysarabia.com
hsara@sas.upenn.edu
University of Pennsylvania
Department of Sociology
Latin American and Latino Studies
Research and Teaching Interests
Migration, race/ethnicity, globalization, human rights, social movements, and qualitative methods.
Academic Appointments
2014-Present
University of Pennsylvania
Postdoctoral Fellow in the Department of Sociology and Latin American and Latino
Studies
Education
University of California, Berkeley, Ph.D. in Sociology
Thesis: “Bordered and Borderless Realities: The Opening and Closing of the U.S.-
Mexico Border to Mexican Nationals.”
Committee: Irene Bloemraad (chair), Cybelle Fox, Cristina Mora, David
Montejano
Qualifying Exam Fields: Sociological Theory, Immigration, and Gender
University of California, Berkeley, M.A. in Sociology
Thesis: “Organizing ‘Below and to the Left’: Differences in the Citizenship and
Transnational Practices of Two Zapatista Groups in the San Francisco Bay Area.”
University of California, Los Angeles, B.A. in Sociology and Chicana/o Studies
Summa Cum Laude
Thesis: “Constructing the Self: An Ethnographic Analysis of Self-Representation
Among Latina Girls at Berendo Middle School.”
Sacramento City College, A.A.
Peer Reviewed Publications
Sarabia, Heidy. 2015. “Global South Cosmopolitans from Mexico: Privilege, Mobility and the
Reinforcement of Difference in the Global South and the Global North.” Ethnic and Racial Studies.
Sarabia, Heidy. 2012. “Perpetual Illegality: Results of Border Enforcement and Policies for Mexican
Undocumented Migrants in the U.S.” Analyses of Social Issues and Public Policy. 12(1):49-67.
Peer Reviewed Publications (continued)
Sarabia, Heidy. 2011. “Organizing ‘Below and to the Left’: Differences in the Citizenship and
Transnational Practices of Two Groups in the San Francisco Bay Area.” Sociological Forum.
Works Under Review and In Progress
Sarabia, Heidy. “The Transnationalization of Illegality: Pressures, Responses, and Consequences of U.S.
Demands on the Mexican State to Filter Irregular Migration.” Under review.
Sarabia, Heidy. “Borderland Attachments: Citizenship and Belonging Along the U.S.-Mexico Border.”
Under review.
Bloemraad, Irene, Heidy Sarabia and Angela Fillingim. “‘Staying out of Trouble:’ Defensive or Active
Citizenship and the Effects of Legal Status on Second-Generation Youth.” (Article under review,
American Behavioral Scientist.)
Bloemraad, Irene, Heidy Sarabia and Angela Fillingim. “Citizenship Acts: Legality, Power and the
Limits of Political Action.” (Book chapter under review for the edited volume Within and Beyond
Citizenship: Lived Experiences of Political Membership, N. Sigona and R. G. Gonzales, editors,
Stanford University Press.)
Sarabia, Heidy. Illegality in the Borderlands: Identity and Belonging among Middle- and Working-
Class Migrants along the U.S.-Mexico Border. Book manuscript in progress.

Presentations
“Human Rights Articulations: Understandings from migrants, discourse from activists, and responses from
institutions along the U.S.-Mexico border.” XXXIII International Congress of the Latin American
Studies Association. San Juan, PR, May 2015.
“Theorizing Transnational Illegality.” Eastern Sociological Association. New York
City, February 2015.
“Gender Violence at the U.S.-Mexico Border.” Sociologist for Women in Society.
Washington D.C. February 2015.
“Mapping the Borderlands: Border-Crossing Practices Along the US-Mexico Border.”
American Sociological Association Annual Conference. San Francisco, CA. August 2014.
“Blending, Bending, and Blurring in the Borderlands: Crossing the US-Mexico Border.” Society for
the Study of Social Problems Annual Conference. San Francisco, CA. August 2014.
“‘Staying out of Trouble:’ Defensive or Active Citizenship and the Effects of Legal Status on Second-
Generation Youth.” Illegality, Youth and Belonging: International Symposium Conference. Harvard
University, October 2013. (with Irene Bloemraad, and Angela Fillingim).
“Human Rigths Along the U.S.-Mexico Border: Articulations from Below and
Responses from Above.” California Sociological Association. Berkeley, CA. October 2013.
Presentations (continued)
“Mapping the Borderlands: Border-Crossing Practices Along the US-Mexico Border.”
American Sociological Association Annual Conference. New York, NY. August 2013.
“Blending, Bending, and Blurring in the Borderlands: Crossing the U.S.-Mexico Border.” Society for
the Study of Social Problems Annual Conference. New York, NY. August 2013.
“Helping Vulnerable Women and Desperate Men: Making sense of micro- and macro-violence against
undocumented men and women along the US-Mexico border.” Sociologist for Women in Society
Regional Meeting. San Francisco, CA. September 2012.
“Global South Cosmopolitans: The Opening and Closing of the U.S.-Mexico Border for Mexican
Tourists.” American Sociological Association Annual Conference. Denver, CO. August 2012.
“From Illegal to Criminal: The Legal and Social Membership of ‘Criminalized’ Migrants deported to
Mexico.” Society for the Study of Social Problems Annual Conference. Denver, CO. August 2012.
“Exiled Mexicans Along the Border: Social and Legal Membership before and after Deportation from
the U.S.” UC Latino Issues Conference. Center for Latino Policy Research. Berkeley, CA. May
“Disciplining Bodies Along the US-Mexico Border: A Comparison of Border Policing and Law
Enforcement in California and Arizona.” Western Historical Association. Oakland, CA. October
“The Makings of Criminalized Perpetual Outlaws: Deporting Long-term US Residents to Mexico.”
American Sociological Association Annual Conference. Las Vegas, NV. August 2011.
“The US-Mexico Border as Liminal Space: Transnational problems, local institutions, and vulnerable
migrants.” Society for the Study of Social Problems Annual Conference. Las Vegas, NE. August
“The Transnationalization of Criminality: Deporting ‘Criminal Aliens.’ Second Annual University of
California International Migration Conference. UC Davis, Davis, CA. February 2011.
“Immigrant Belonging: Conceptions of Citizenship and American Identity.” Institute for the Study of
Social Change Research Symposium. UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA. May 2009.
“Belonging in ‘A World Where Many Worlds Fit’: Differences in the citizenship practices of two
Zapatista groups.” National Association of Ethnic Studies. San Diego, CA. April 2009.
“Illegality in Academia.” SBES/AGEP Conference. UC Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA. May 2007.
“Citizenship in Academia.” Changing the Culture of Academia Conference. UC Berkeley, Berkeley,
CA. March 2007
“Constructing the Self: An ethnographic analysis of self-presentation among girls at Berendo Middle
School.” Annual Alpha Kappa Delta (Sociological Honor Association) Conference. UC Los
Angeles, Los Angeles, CA. May 2003.
“Women in Top Academic Professions: The Supply Angle.” Annual Summer Research Opportunity
Program Symposium. UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA. July 2002.
Research Experience
Prof. Emilio Parrado, Prof. Chenoa Flippen, and Prof. Amada Armenta, Sociology and
Demography , University of Pennsylvania
On the South Philadelphia Research Project, I am in charge of supervising the collection
of surveys in South Philadelphia among recent immigrants from Latin America, as well as
conducting in-depth interviews with key informants in order to contextualize the
quantitative findings.
Prof. Shannon Gleeson, Latin American and Latino Studies, UC Santa Cruz [now at Cornell]
I am in charge of conducting phone interviews with representatives of organizations
throughout the United States that provide services and resources for Mexican immigrants.
Center for Science & Education Opportunity, UC San Francisco
I was in charge of guiding focus-group discussions with Spanish-speaking immigrant
parents about their college-bound children.
Prof. Irene Bloemraad, Institute for the Study of Social Change, UC Berkeley
I conducted interviews, coded and analyzed interview data, and wrote theoretical memos
about the political socialization of immigrant parents and their U.S.-born citizen children.
Prof. Edward Telles, Sociology Department, UC Los Angeles
I coded and analyzed statistical data and wrote theoretical memos about the educational
pipeline of Latinos.
Prof. Cristina Pons, Chicana/o Studies Dept., UC Los Angeles
I developed a literature review of Mexican writers.
Professional Affiliations
American Sociological Association
Society for the Study of Social Problems
Sociologist for Women in Society
Eastern Sociological Association
California Sociological Association

Languages
English and Spanish: writing, reading and verbal fluency
